newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Term of Belgium's Verplaetse extended until 1999.
newsitem.headline: Term of Belgium's Verplaetse extended until 1999.

text.p: Belgian central bank governor Alfons Verplaetse can stay in his post until 1999 in spite of reaching the age at which under Belgian law he should retire later this year, Belgian paper De Standaard said on Friday.

King Albert on Thursday ratified a decision by the four parties making up the ruling centre-left coalition that Verplaetse should remain at the helm of the National Bank until the start of European economic and monetary union in 1999.
Verplaetse will be 67 on February 19 and would normally have to give up his post then, but he had offered to serve two more years.
The paper said the government parties wanted to prevent changes to the team preparing Belgium for EMU.
Verplaetse, as the architect of government policy to bring down the country's debt mountain, has played a key role in trying to ensure Belgium meets the Maastricht Treaty criteria for EMU entry.
Verplaetse has been at the head of the National Bank since July 1989.
